description: From Spackle, originally a brand name, perhaps based on spachtel which is ultimately from Latin spatula.

entries.meaning: Any powder (originally containing gypsum plaster and glue) that when mixed with water forms a plastic paste, which is used to fill cracks and holes in plaster.
A plastic paste meant for filling cracks and holes in plaster.
A paste-like substance that fills a gap.

verbs.description: spackle (third-person singular simple present spackles, present participle spackling, simple past and past participle spackled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fill or repair with a plastic paste.
(intransitive) To fill cracks or holes with a spackle.
To fill gaps with something, as if spackling; to speckle
examples: The neighborhood has been spackled with coffee shops.
